The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said it would compete in the elections despite calls for a boycott. Mohamed Badie, the new chief of the party, said they would contest 30 percent of the seats.<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/10/201010911379428759.html</ref>
The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said it would compete in the elections despite calls for a boycott. Mohamed Badie, the new chief of the party, said they would contest 30 percent of the seats.<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/10/201010911379428759.html</ref>
â
A former adviser to the Muslim Brotherhood, Abdel Hamid al-Ghazaly, said that whil the party had brokered a deal with the governing National Democratic Party during the 2005 parliamentary election, no such deal would be agreed to this year. He also said Egyptians voted Brotherhood in 2005 to show their dissatisfaction with the ruling regime. "They werenât necessarily fond of us. [But] we have no political life whatsoever, thanks to the regime. We canât even be compared with the most backward countries of the world. Participation in this yearâs parliamentary election is the only hope for the Muslim Brothers to get out of the predicament they are in." A [[Tagammu]] party member, Abul Ez al-Hariri, also suggested the deals that the opposition parties signed resulted in a loss of credibility and consequent inability to play an effective role in politics. "They have become advocates of the regime."<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/no-ndp-muslim-brotherhood-deal-over-impending-elections-says-former-mb-adviser</ref>
+
A former adviser to the Muslim Brotherhood, Abdel Hamid al-Ghazaly, said that whil the party had brokered a deal with the governing National Democratic Party during the 2005 parliamentary election, no such deal would be agreed to this year. He also said Egyptians voted Brotherhood in 2005 to show their dissatisfaction with the ruling regime. "They werenât necessarily fond of us. [But] we have no political life whatsoever, thanks to the regime. We canât even be compared with the most backward countries of the world. Participation in this yearâs parliamentary election is the only hope for the Muslim Brothers to get out of the predicament they are in." A [[National Progressive Unionist Party|Tagammu]] party member, Abul Ez al-Hariri, also suggested the deals that the opposition parties signed resulted in a loss of credibility and consequent inability to play an effective role in politics. "They have become advocates of the regime."<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/no-ndp-muslim-brotherhood-deal-over-impending-elections-says-former-mb-adviser</ref>
